bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, December 12, 1928

div1.p: Carter plans to work through the Christmas holidays.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, December 12, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Frost
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
December 12, 1928 Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Your letter of December 11th. reached me this morning. Of course,
I'm not only “not averse to working” during the Christmas holidays, but
shall be very grateful to go over to Baltimore at that time and work
with you for as long as is convenient to you. Re the above, I did not
understand from Susan's telephone conversation that I was being in-
vited over for any but festive purposes, hence my letter to her last
night, saying that I did not feel that I ought to accept. My reason
being that Miss Brown and I were expecting to use up the remainder of
her leave, on work for the book, about the time for which Susan had
asked me over. Now, of course, we will try to “put things through”
before I leave for Baltimore.

Had a hectic session at the Carnegie with Morley to-day and got
a lot more done than I anticipated. Will write you details within a
day or two--the latter probably, as Morley did more in indicating the
sources from which I could complete certain lines of inquiry than he
did in furnishing specific data. He did both, however, and our confer-
ence was well worth while. Incidentally, he told me that I had my mater-
ial better prepared for handling in short order than anyone with whom he
had ever worked. I told him that was inevitable with anyone of average
intelligence who had been associated with yourself and Father.

I shall probably work at home to-morrow as Miss Brown is just get-
ting over a cold and I can't afford to catch it and “get sick and die” until
the work on the book is done. After that a swift and economical demise
demise would be decidedly preferable to another illness like that of
last winter. Father said youone generally “stayed dead even longer than
it takes even to get over “flu,” but so far as the latter part of his
statement is concerned, I'm still “from Missouri.” Glad am I that you
are really feeling “quite well again,” after so severe an attack as you
must have had!

With much love to the Susans, and thank you ever so much for
planning to use your holidays in work on the book--there is no other
way in which I should be so glad to spend themmine this year.

closer.seg:
P. S. Got a delightful letter from Dr. Vincent to-day. He had had a
bad spill, his horse having slipped and thrown him and then rolled over
him--fortunately the latter happened so quickly that no serious injury
was done.
